instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi i have this board not power no led on magsafe
where can I start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Any history available?
Did you test with fake charger, or lab PSU?

Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Fake charger but  work fine 
it suddenly turned off
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=8.58
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>=3.53

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Then post these voltages with original charger too.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=3.3

threads.message:
I tried the Lio card on another board and on the other card the fan works, but on that one too no light but it works
on lab psu it has an absorption of 0.02

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Then no Magsafe light is caused by LIO board.
It worked in other machine with fake, or original charger?

threads.message: ok with new Lio Board I have orange light but the fan doesn't spin and I have an absorption of 0.02

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=3.297
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=3.328

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: From 3.4 at 0.342

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Then check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

Trying to start in SMC bypass is also worth to try.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>=5V
even if pulse always remains at 5V
SMC Bypass I don't know how to do it
I found <CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7400</CAPACITOR> with liquid damage. I replaced them but nothing changed
Could <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> be the problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>=5V"
Please re-check.
PCH doesn't admit 5V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Sorry <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>=0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
No pulse at all?
Did you check at exact time when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

"SMC Bypass I don't know how to do it"
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]
Google also knows...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I tried to measure by making the bridge but <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>=0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
You must make temporar contact; like pressing power button.

Check <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and the 4 PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> From 3.4 to 0
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> from 3.2 stay at 3.2
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> from 3.2 stay at 3.2
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  from 3.4 stay at 3.4

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Check these before pressing power button.
What about RTC signals?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Possibly accumulated crap underneath PCH.
Try heating with quality flux.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
PCH=CPU?
Is it possible that I have <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR> shorted?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
"PCH=CPU?"
No, but both are embedded in the same package!

"I have <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR> shorted?"
We can't know more than you.
You didn't post any reading about it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I was comparing 2 identical boards and I realized that on the board that doesn't work <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR> is shorted. I wanted to know if it was possible to understand if that is the problem

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Very likely CPU is shorted, not the capacitor.
Lift (one side) L7310/20 and check where the short remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: short remain in l7310

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Really?
Can we know which SIDE of the coil?
